Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Investigating Intermolecular Interactions in the Formation of Polymer-Based Nanowires
Award.AbstractNarration:
Semiconducting polymers promise to deliver low cost electronic devices such as solar cells and transistors due to their easy processabililty. Fabrication conditions have been identified that allows poly(3-hexyl thiophenes) (P3HT), an extensively studied semiconducting polymer, to crystallize into nanowires (NWs), which can improve a solar cell?s efficiency. This project aims to understand the assembly of P3HT into NWs. Both the NW alignment and the orientation of the polymer chains with respect to the substrate are crucial parameters to control for ensuring efficient transport of charges in solar cells. In order to characterize the structural features of the NWs, near edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS), a highly specialized technique capable of proving the molecular orientation of thin films down to monolayers of the material will be used. Dr. Kilwon Cho, an expert in surface and electronic device characterization at Pohang University of Science and Technology, will be the host for this research, providing a U.S. graduate student vital access and expertize for NEXAFS analysis.

This project will focus on the surface crystallization of P3HT from graphene deposited on supporting substrates. Utilizing a metastable solution of P3HT, with a strong driving force for crystallization that is not sufficient to induce homogenous crystallization, NWs of P3HT will be formed selectively on graphene. During the crystallization, the polymer chains in solution interact with graphene and the underlying substrate. A systematic study of the NW growth from graphene deposited on modified substrates employing surface characterization techniques such as NEXAFS will unveil the surface properties and the morphology evolution of P3HT. This will help us determine the effects of intermolecular forces on the P3HT crystallization. Ultimately, the beneficial effects of the NWs will be assessed by the fabrication and characterization of solar cells. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Korea.

This award is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Korea.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Semiconducting polymers promise to deliver low cost electronic devices, such as solar cells and transistors, due to their easy processabililty in solution. Fabrication conditions have been identified that allow poly(3-hexyl thiophene) (P3HT), an extensively studied semiconducting polymer, to crystallize into nanowires (NWs), which can improve solar cells efficiency. This project aims to understand the assembly of P3HT into NWs. Both the NW alignment and the orientation of the polymer chains with respect to the substrate are crucial parameters to control for ensuring efficient charge transport in solar cells. The goal of the project is to simultaneously control the molecular and nanostructural organization of poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) through solution-based crystallization. Ideally the P3HT chains must be oriented “face-on” (i.e. the π planes parallel to the substrate normal) with respect to the substrate allowing the polymer to crystallize into vertically aligned nanowires. Consequently, this control over the morphology would improve the performance of solar cells by providing pathways for out-of-plane charge transport.

It was demonstrated that P3HT selectively crystallized into nanowires from graphene on MoO3, which can serve both as a template for nanowire growth and an anode for solar cells. The main requirement for selective crystallization was a metastable solution of P3HT at room temperature. The metastable state of the solutions suppresses homogenous nucleation of crystals while allowing for heterogeneous crystallization on nucleation sites. In the dissolved state, the polymer chains in solution interact with graphene, initially adsorbing “face-on”, but transitioning to “edge-on” (i.e. π planes perpendicular to the substrate) as the film grew thicker and the solvent was removed. The transition of the P3HT orientation was confirmed by ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy and near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratories. As determined by grazing incidence wide angle X-ray scattering, the initial face-on conformation is partially preserved by embedding the P3HT structures in an indene C60 bisadduct (ICBA) matrix, when compared to pristine P3HT films. This study establishes a platform for generating vertically oriented nanowires to be employed in solar cells and thereby improving their power conversion efficiency. Results were achieved in a synergetic collaboration between the groups of Kilwon Cho at Pohang University of Science and Technology and Bumjoon J. Kim at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST), and the Pohang Accelerator Laboratories.

At the end of the EAPSI Program, I had the pleasure of presenting my work at the NRF headquarters to the NRF staff members. Also, NRF Global PhD fellows were able to share their respective research results with the EAPSI participants. To reach a broader audience I traveled to the 2015 SACNAS National Conference. The Society of Advancing Chicanos and Native Americans in Science (SACNAS) gathers many of the nation’s best scientists possessing similar backgrounds to mine. Therefore, I had the opportunity to provide underrepresented groups with the knowledge of international research opportunities. Coupled with SACNAS, the Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers (SHPE) allowed me to serve as role model to positively impact the Hispanic community.
